TopicTitle: Orbital Bombardment from Retrograde Solar Orbit

Articles.Content:
A while ago, Scott Manley made a video about re-entering Kerbin's atmosphere from a retrograde orbit, at 19km/s. Now, I thought about an interesting purpose of this: A Rod from the Gods. How much more effective would a RFTG be when launched from retrograde solar orbit, than simply from low Kerbin orbit?

A test with Sal Vager's RFTG mod may be useful.

Preliminary testing with a modded cockpit with mass 100 tonnes and drag value 0.01 and atmo entry speed 19km/s, gives an impact velocity of 15.8km/s (mach 45), and a penetration depth of about 100m. This is mind numbingly impressive, as KSP does not simulate hypervelocity ground penetration!

Impact pic:

If the altimeter above is accurate, I actually penetrated about 1.5km.

Dropping my test pod from orbit (entry velocity 2.1km/s) causes an impact velocity of about 1km/s.

This means that the RSO rod brings 69% of its energy to the ground, and the LKO rod only 23%. From E=0.5mv^2, assuming no mass loss.

Not if you have some knowledge about how these things work and make it a rod of tungsten with a decent ballistic coefficient (long and pointy). Look at the beginning of thethread to see what percentage of the energy gets dissipated as heat. Then divide by the energy necessary to vaporize each unit of mass of tungsten. Increase mass so final impact mass is the one you want, by perhaps a few of kilograms per delivered ton.

Rune. It's called ablative heatshield, and tungsten makes a hell of a good one.
